text: this is Steven Ferrell for the New York
Times at around 12:15 the Verrazano
Bridge was still closed and there was a
long line of people waiting to get
across Manhattan Beach resident mayor
riggan was one he said his house was
flooded and he was traveling to New
Jersey to see his family as they open up
any minute but looks like they're
waiting for the wind to die down so I'm
returning convenience is it within
minutes the wait was over the police
opened the bridge and traffic started
flowing
it's 1:30 in the afternoon and the hue
l-khayri tunnel formerly the Brooklyn
Battery Tunnel is still closed red and
white lights are flashing at the
entrance and all the lanes are just a
sea of yellow stop signs and read no
entry the scene was the same at the
Queens Midtown Tunnel although by now
like the Verrazano other bridges were
open meanwhile on the streets of
Brooklyn things began to get back to
some semblance of normality residents
were out for a stroll checking out the
height of the infamous Gowanus Canal a
litmus for flooding in the neighborhood
the water remains higher than normal and
there's a lot of work ahead and we're
seeing a lot of the people in the
neighborhood pumping water out of their
basements or the ground floors
